Award.AwardTitle: CSEDI Collaborative Research: Investigating the Nature of the Subcontinental Upper Mantle
Award.AbstractNarration:
Earth's continents have been assembled via amalgamation of land masses over geologic time, eventually forming stable continental interiors, with associated tectonic activity and deformation typically isolated to the periphery of the continent. Over time, successive episodes of deformation in the form of extension, compression, magmatism, accretion, and rifting have left the sub-continental upper mantle with a complex signature of thermal and chemical variability. Many ancient continental areas have been modified by relatively recent dynamic processes, for example active volcanism, rifting, and subduction at continental edges contribute to a complex sub-continental mantle. Of particular interest is the history and influence of melting, melt production, melt migration, and melt storage in sub-continental upper mantle, as it provides a window into past and present dynamical processes, including the formation of continents. This multi-disciplinary project will provide a systematic and geographically-detailed investigation of the dynamical, chemical, and thermal processes at work within the sub-continental upper mantle and their relationships to past and present melting within the Earth. The research team links a primarily undergraduate institution with a research institution and will include training of a postdoctoral researcher, undergraduate researchers through online and face-to-face research collaborations. These connections will be strengthened through long-term cross-institutional research experiences and the inclusion of a pre-service teacher working with the researchers to develop curricular activities describing Earth structure for high school and undergraduate classrooms.

This two-year project will develop and apply rock physics models of melt, material mineralogies, and rheologies against observables provided by complementary seismic approaches, providing a comprehensive characterization of the velocity and density structure within the sub-continental upper mantle. The team will investigate the hypothesis that seismic signatures within the sub-continental upper mantle are relatable to past or current episodes of partial melting, and that they bear the fingerprints of thermal, chemical, and dynamical processes brought about by convective motions and mantle flow, both past and present. They will decipher these signals by: 1) using four seismic tools sensitive to absolute shear and compressional wavespeeds, their relative variations, as well as impedance contrasts, discontinuity sharpness, and anisotropic structure, 2) through geodynamic modeling of the seismic observables to quantify whether the presence of melt (or remnant, frozen-in melt) is consistent with the observed seismic structures, and 3) comparison of the inferred models to predictions for mantle rheology, electrical conductivity, temperatures, and composition, and the relationship of variations in these parameters to tectonic evolution and dynamical settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth's continents have been assembled via amalgamation of land masses over geologic time, eventually forming stable continental interiors, with associated tectonic activity and deformation typically isolated to the periphery of the continent. Over time, successive episodes of deformation in the form of extension, compression, magmatism, accretion, and rifting have left the sub-continental upper mantle with a complex signature of thermal and chemical variability. Many ancient continental areas have been modified by relatively recent dynamic processes, for example active volcanism, rifting, and subduction at continental edges contribute to a complex sub-continental mantle. 

Our multi-disciplinary project provided a systematic and geographically-detailed investigation of the dynamical, chemical, and thermal processes at work within the sub-continental upper mantle and deeper, and the relationship to past and present dynamics within the Earth. Our research team linked a primarily undergraduate institution (University of Wisconsin-Whitewater) with a research institution (University of Maryland) and included training of a two postdoctoral researchers, summer research opportunities for undergraduate research students, and graduate student research at the University of Maryland. The research was presented at national and international conferences, and led to the publication of multiple peer-reviewed articles in the scientific literature.

Our project determined mantle structure across a wide variety of depths, with our seismic probes providing sensitivity from the mantle lithosphere down to the deepest portions of the mid-mantle. A primary result of our project was the nearly global detection of a wide variety of scatterers at 850-1000 km depth, and characterization of these boundaries in depth and seismic strength. This result was unexpected and suggests that mantle convection may introduce heterogeneity beneath the Earth's mantle transition zone, perhaps arising from contamination of the mid-mantle by subducted lithosphere or positions of ancient continents.

Measurements made on seismic surface waves provide some of the best constraints on how properties vary with depth in and below the lithosphere. Joint inversions of Love and Rayleigh waves (the two types of surface waves) have been used to make inferences about flow in the crust and mantle, which carries implications for plate tectonics, mantle convection, and the building of mountains and basins. Using a new inversion framework we developed supported partially by this project, we were able to assess how commonly-made choices in inversions might influence inferences on flow when using surface wave data. This work led us to identify important tradeoffs that must be considered when making inferences about flow, and to propose a novel way of performing inversions.

Finally, we have developed a Bayesian inversion approach to constrain the properties of the crust, lithosphere, and underlying asthenosphere, by combining information from surface waves, receiver functions, and reflection seismology. Upon applying these techniques to the study of continental crust and underlying mantle, we came to the surprising discovery that joint inversions in sedimented regions can lead to spurious low velocity zones within the continental lithosphere. We demonstrates that these artifacts arise from inconsistencies between surface wave and receiver function data, since the latter are strongly affected by thin sedimentary cover while the former might be insensitive to its presence. We have also devised a way of eliminating these artifacts, which is important because spurious low velocity zones have been misinterpreted in the literature as indicating the presence of melt and anomalous composition. 

The inversion tools we have developed as part of this project provide a new way for quantifying the acceptable solutions and uncertainties in structures, with implications for inferences concerning the thermal, chemical, and dynamical properties of the Earth.
